title: Reported Speech
description: Learn how to report what other people say.

rules.title: Direct vs. Reported Speech
rules.explanation: Direct speech uses the exact words someone said (with quotation marks). Reported speech tells what someone said without using their exact words.

examples.sentence: Reported: She said (that) she was tired.

rules.title: Tense Changes in Reported Speech
rules.explanation: When reporting speech, tenses usually shift back one step: present → past, past → past perfect, will → would.

examples.sentence: "I work here." → He said he worked there.
examples.translation: "나 여기서 일해." → 그는 거기서 일한다고 했다.

examples.sentence: "I will help you." → She said she would help me.
"I have finished." → He said he had finished.

rules.title: Pronoun and Time Changes
rules.explanation: When reporting speech, pronouns and time expressions often change to match the reporter's perspective.

examples.sentence: "I'll call you tomorrow." → He said he would call me the next day.
examples.translation: "내일 전화할게." → 그는 다음 날 전화하겠다고 했다.

examples.sentence: "I'm leaving now." → She said she was leaving then.

rules.title: Reporting Questions
rules.explanation: When reporting questions, use 'if/whether' for yes/no questions and question words for wh-questions. Use statement word order (no question mark).

examples.sentence: "Are you coming?" → She asked if I was coming.
"Where do you live?" → He asked where I lived.
"What time is it?" → She asked what time it was.
examples.note: No question mark in reported speech

rules.title: Reporting Commands and Requests
rules.explanation: Use 'tell/ask + object + to + infinitive' to report commands and requests.

examples.sentence: "Please help me." → She asked me to help her.
"Don't be late!" → He told me not to be late.
"Sit down." → The teacher told us to sit down.

rules.title: Reporting Verbs
rules.explanation: Different reporting verbs can be used to show how something was said: say, tell, ask, explain, promise, admit, suggest, etc.

examples.sentence: He promised that he would come.
She suggested going to a restaurant.
He explained that he had been stuck in traffic.

exercises.question: "I am happy." → She said she _____ happy.
"I will call you later." → He said he _____ call me later.
"Do you like coffee?" → She asked _____ I liked coffee.
"Where do you live?" → He asked where I _____.
"Please help me." → She asked me _____ help her.
"Don't be late!" → He told me _____ to be late.
"I have finished my work." → She said she _____ finished her work.
"I'll meet you tomorrow." → He said he would meet me the _____ day.
She _____ that she was feeling sick.
He _____ me that he would be late for the meeting.
Put in order: said / she / tired / that / was / she
exercises.answer: She said that she was tired.

exercises.question: "Can you help me?" → She asked _____ I could help her.
